entry.title: mpskit
entry.summary: C++17 toolkit to study the static properties of discrete quantum systems.

entry.title: Benchmarking and Frequency Scaling
entry.summary: In some benchmarking scenarios it might be necessary to disable CPU frequency scaling. I explain how to achieve this easily using the cpupower tool.
entry.content:
Modern CPUs employ frequency scaling techniques to adapt the frequency of their cores depending on the number of active cores as well as temperature and power constraints. In some scenarios this is undesirable when benchmarking the performance of a program. I recently encountered this problem when trying to benchmark a scientific code. I wanted to investigate its performance measured by its execution time in different parameter regimes. Since, the program under consideration is single-threaded it seems only natural to run multiple instances at once. Unfortunately, this leads to the aforementioned issue. Some runs might end earlier than others such that the number of active CPU cores reduces, and the active cores can run at a higher frequency. This would distort the runtime results since the program would suddenly run faster on these cores. So I explored how I could limit the CPU to a fixed maximum frequency that it can run at independent of the number of active jobs.

The first idea is to enter the UEFI and disabling the frequency scaling and turbo boost altogether. On my work machine sporting an Intel i5-9500 this leads to all cores only running at the base frequency of 3GHz. This potentially leaves a lot of performance on the table.

A better way is to use the cpupower tool to limit the maximum frequency the CPU cores get boost to. But what frequency should you specify here? To answer this I ran one compute job per physical CPU core — six jobs in my case. This will yield the maximum load the CPU can encounter during the benchmark. Hyper-threading is not available on my machine and the code performance scales differently across these logical cores such that it is best avoided in my case. I monitored the CPU frequency using the command

1
watch -n 0.5 -x sh -c "cat /proc/cpuinfo | grep MHz"

and saw that initially the CPU cores boosted above 4GHz. However, as the temperature of the cores increased (which I monitored using the excellent btop) the frequency dropped. Therefore, I waited one hour for the system to reach a thermal equilibrium where the temperature is settled, and the CPU frequency would only fluctuate on a very small scale (in my case between 3640MHz and 3650MHz). From these observations I decided to run my CPU at 3600MHz leaving a small buffer should the frequency drop a bit more in very long runs (in the order of a few days).

The maximum frequency can than be set using the command

1
sudo cpupower frequency-set --max 3600MHz --governor performance

On my system it was important to specify the CPU frequency scaling governor. Otherwise, the limit would only be effective when exploiting all cores. The cores could still exceed this limit if not all of them were active.

It might be that on your system these governors are called a little different. Calling cpupower frequency-info will list the available governors and also show you the hardware frequency limits. Also, there exist other ways to influence CPU frequency behavior which are beyond the scope of this short blog post. However, as usual the Archlinux Wiki has some nice information on this topic!

entry.title: Refactoring a Large Snakefile
entry.summary: I describe how I simplified my life with a little restructuring of a complex Snakefile.
entry.content:
I really enjoy using snakemake for my analysis workflows in my PhD projects. However, in a current project of mine the Snakefile rapidly grew in complexity due to the addition of more and more analyses. This lead to two problems

  1. The Snakefile quickly became hard to read and maintain.
  2. The AFS the universities was problematic.

Modularizing the Snakefile

Initially, my project structure looked as follows:

1
project/
2
├── config.yaml
3
├── Snakefile
4
├── .snakemake/
5
│   ├── …
6
│   ├── metadata
7
│   └── …
8
├── dataset1
9
├── dataset2
10
├── dataset3
11
└── …

There was only one main Snakefile containing all analysis that ran across multiple datasets. snakemake stores all its files (metadata, lock files, etc.) in the .snakemake directory. First, I wanted to tackle the issue of readability/maintainability. My workflow consists of multiple different types of analyses each consisting of potentially multiple subtasks. However, these analyses are different from each other or in the language of snakemake:

The full DAG of jobs consists of multiple disconnected DAGs for each analysis.

Therefore, it makes a sense to place all independent analyses in their own Snakefile leading to the following directory structure:

1
project/
2
├── config.yaml
3
├── Snakefile
4
├── Snakefiles/
5
│   ├── analysis1/
6
│   │   └── Snakefile
7
│   ├── analysis2/
8
│   │   └── Snakefile
9
│   └── …
10
├── .snakemake/
11
│   ├── …
12
│   ├── metadata
13
│   └── …
14
├── dataset1
15
├── dataset2
16
└── …

I added a rule in the Snakefile for each analysis that would depend on all resulting files of the analysis such that I could reference in a main Snakefile in the root of the project. The rule I added looks something like this:

1
rule analysis1_all:
2
    input:
3
        …
4
    output:
5
        ".analysis1.all"
6
    shell:
7
        "touch {output}"

The main Snakefile can then be written as follows

1
configfile: "config.yaml"
2
3
include: "Snakefiles/analysis1/Snakefile"
4
include: "Snakefiles/analysis2/Snakefile"
5
…
6
7
rule all:
8
    input:
9
        ".analysis1.all",
10
        ".analysis2.all",
11
        …


This makes maintaining the project a lot easier.




1
project/
2
├── config.yaml
3
├── Snakefile
4
├── Snakefiles/
5
│   ├── analysis1/
6
│   │   └── Snakefile
7
│   ├── analysis2/
8
│   │   └── Snakefile
9
│   └── …
10
├── .snakemake → .snakecache/analysis1/
11
├── .snakecache/
12
│   ├── analysis1/
13
│   │   ├── …
14
│   │   ├── metadata
15
│   │   └── …
16
│   ├── analysis2/
17
│   │   ├── …
18
│   │   ├── metadata
19
│   │   └── …
20
│   └── …
21
├── dataset1
22
├── dataset2
23
└── …

entry.title: code2html
entry.summary: Small JS library to render code to HTML using various backends.
entry.content:
code2html

Render source code to HTML using Prism.js or Highlight.js.

For instructions please consult the help message -h/--help for now.

entry.title: pelican-syntax-highlighting
entry.summary: Syntax highlighting for your pelican site using various backends.
entry.content:
Syntax Highlighting: A Plugin for Pelican

Highlight syntax using Prism.js, Highlight.js or Pygments

Installation

This plugin can be installed via:

python -m pip install pelican-syntax-highlighting

Usage

<>

Contributing

Contributions are welcome and much appreciated. Every little bit helps. You can contribute by improving the documentation, adding missing features, and fixing bugs. You can also help out by reviewing and commenting on existing issues.

To start contributing to this plugin, review the Contributing to Pelican documentation, beginning with the Contributing Code section.

License

This project is licensed under the AGPL-3.0 license.

entry.title: Installing a Specific Build of an Anaconda Package
entry.summary: This blog post shows how to install a specific build of an Anaconda package.
entry.content:
Recently, I wrote a small python program to perform computations in parallel using the MPI exposed by the mpi4py library. By using the convenient h5py library, I store the results in a single, large HDF5 file. This however required the parallel HDF5 support to be compiled into the HDF5 library. Naturally, the first step is to check whether an Anaconda package is available that includes the MPI support. Running conda search h5py I found the following available packages:

1
Loading channels: done
2
# Name Version Build                      Channel
3
…
4
h5py   3.4.0   mpi_mpich_py37h3a1f665_0   conda-forge
5
h5py   3.4.0   mpi_mpich_py37h3a1f665_1   conda-forge
6
h5py   3.4.0   mpi_mpich_py38h211b2b0_0   conda-forge
7
h5py   3.4.0   mpi_mpich_py38h211b2b0_1   conda-forge
8
h5py   3.4.0   mpi_mpich_py39ha1f86df_0   conda-forge
9
h5py   3.4.0   mpi_mpich_py39ha1f86df_1   conda-forge
10
h5py   3.4.0   mpi_openmpi_py37hc2f5ef6_0 conda-forge
11
h5py   3.4.0   mpi_openmpi_py37hc2f5ef6_1 conda-forge
12
h5py   3.4.0   mpi_openmpi_py38h63e9fd9_0 conda-forge
13
h5py   3.4.0   mpi_openmpi_py38h63e9fd9_1 conda-forge
14
h5py   3.4.0   mpi_openmpi_py39hb889842_0 conda-forge
15
h5py   3.4.0   mpi_openmpi_py39hb889842_1 conda-forge
16
h5py   3.4.0   nompi_py37hd308b1e_100     conda-forge
17
h5py   3.4.0   nompi_py37hd308b1e_101     conda-forge
18
h5py   3.4.0   nompi_py38hfbb2109_100     conda-forge
19
h5py   3.4.0   nompi_py38hfbb2109_101     conda-forge
20
h5py   3.4.0   nompi_py39h7e08c79_100     conda-forge
21
h5py   3.4.0   nompi_py39h7e08c79_101     conda-forge

I truncated the output to only show the 3.4.0 version, which is the most recent one and the one I want to use. We can clearly identify three different builds:

  1. nompi: no MPI support (default)
  2. mpi_mpich: MPI support via the MPICH implementation
  3. openmpi: MPI support via the OpenMPI implementation

For my small project I decided to install a build using the MPICH implementation. However, it was unclear to me what the syntax for specifying the build is. I could not find anything in the documentation.

The first thing I found by searching the wider web was to use the syntax

1
conda install <package_name>=<version>=<build_string>

For example

1
conda install h5py=3.4.0=mpi_mpich_py39ha1f86df_1

The latest version can be installed using wildcards

1
conda install "h5py=*=mpi_mpich_*"

By exporting my Anaconda environment via conda export --from-history then showed me that there is another, more concise syntax. We can just specify the package as h5py[build=mpi_mpich_*] or h5py[build=mpi_*] if we do not care about the actual MPI implementation. Due to the extensive dependency resolution process conda includes the MPI implementation as a dependency and installs it.

I found this piece of information regarding build strings in the conda-build documentation:

The build string. May not contain "-". Differentiates builds of packages with otherwise identical names and versions, such as:

  • A build with other dependencies, such as Python 3.4 instead of Python 2.7.
  • A bug fix in the build process.
  • Some different optional dependencies, such as MKL versus ATLAS linkage. Nothing in conda actually inspects the build string. Strings such as np18py34_1 are designed only for human readability and conda never parses them.

Which tells us that these build strings are just a human-readable identifier for the package and no actual information is extracted from them. conda install seems to perform some pattern matching using this string, i.e. it is ok to only specify the start of the build string and to use wildcards.

So the strategy seems when installing a specific variant of an Anaconda package seems to be:

  1. Perform a conda search for the package.
  2. Identify the build string.
  3. Install the dependency by invoking conda install <package>[build=<build_string_pattern>] and using a proper build string pattern (e.g. use only the start of the build string and employ wildcards where necessary).

entry.title: Taming git-annex using git-config and gitattributes
entry.summary: Git-annex allows to track (large) files with git without adding their contents to the repository. git-config and gitattributes allow to prevent from accidentally annexing files which can be a major nuisance.
entry.content:
Recently, I started using git-annex again which is a great tool to track large files in the git version control system without actually adding their contents to git. It is very versatile and allows for the usage of many storage backends. However, proper care has to be taken when working with mixed content, i.e. some files that should be tracked by git directly and some which should be stored using git-annex. To my understanding, git-annex wants to annex every file and I messed up repositories a couple of times running git annex sync and other related commands. All my files ended up being annexed which is definitely not what I tried to achieve. Even though this is easily reversible this behavior is often not ideal.

Since I really like git-annex in general, I wanted to find a way around this issue. After some research I found that the documentation states that there are two ways to gain fine control over which files will be annexed. I still wanted to write this short post, since it took me a while to discover that one should tune git-annex in this way. For both approaches it is important that git-annex tries to annex every file that it considers to be large. Luckily, we can control this classification.

git-config

The simplest way is to rune the following git-config command:

1
git annex config --set annex.largefiles 'largerthan=100kb and not (include=*.c or include=*.h)'

This will instruct git-annex to consider every file larger than 100kb to be large except for .c and .h files. Every file that matches these criteria will be annexed.

The command above sets the configuration for git-annex globally, i.e. for every clone of the repository. We can also set this for the current clone only, but I do not find that to be particularly useful (see the documentation on how to do this).

gitattributes

The approach using git-config quickly becomes complicated when we want to achieve very fine-grained control, e.g. setting largerthan limits per file type or dealing with many cases. Luckily, we can also control the largefiles behavior using gitattributes. The following .gitattributes file will achieve the same behavior as the aforementioned git-config command:

1
* annex.largefiles=largerthan=100kb
2
*.c annex.largefiles=nothing
3
*.h annex.largefiles=nothing

However, this allows us to be much more flexible and adding new cases just requires adding some lines in the .gitattributes file. Due to the way git looks for .gitattributes files (see gitattributes documentation) starting from the current directory and moving up the file system tree, we can easily change the behavior of git-annex in subdirectories by overriding the attributes.

Conclusion

Using these two techniques I finally convinced git-annex to operate in the way I wanted it too rendering it very useful to work with mixed content (e.g. for machine learning projects or when taking online courses). And yes, this requires some manual labor and consideration regarding which files we want annex but overall I believe this is actually a positive aspect. There are some advanced topics like forcefully annexing small files and converting between git controlled content and git-annexed files which are beyond the scope of this article but are well documented.

entry.title: Continuously Linting Ansible Playbooks and Roles
entry.summary: The ansible-lint linter for Ansible YAML can be easily set up as a GitHub workflow, continuously checking playbooks and roles.
entry.content:
ansible-lint is a helpful tool when dealing with Ansible roles and playbooks. It can help find common mistakes, prevent bugs and generally improve the code quality. Using the pre-commit framework it is trivial to set it up as hook in the Git version control system such that it checks the code before creating a commit. Sometimes however, one might forget to run pre-commit install after checking out a project or a collaborator is not using pre-commit. Therefore, it is helpful to set ansible-lint up as a GitHub workflow that is executed automatically on every commit and pull request. Of course this implies that one uses the GitHub platform. Other hosting services might offer other ways of achieving the same goal as well, but we focus on GitHub here.

In this repository an unofficial GitHub action can be found. However, I had no success with it. I identified the following problems:

  • It uses outdated versions of the ansible and the ansible-lint Python packages.
  • While the versions can be overridden I still could not get it to run.
  • The action creates a Docker container which makes the action rather slow.

Since ansible-lint is a simple Python package and creating a Docker image seems a bit like overshooting, I set up a GitHub workflow myself. I created the file .github/workflows/ansible-lint.yml (can be named differently as well) with the following content:

1
name: lint
2
on: [push, pull_request]
3
4
jobs:
5
  build:
6
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
7
    steps:
8
      - uses: actions/checkout@v2
9
      - name: Set up Python 3.9
10
        uses: actions/setup-python@v2
11
        with:
12
          python-version: 3.9
13
      - uses: actions/cache@v2
14
        with:
15
          path: ~/.cache/pip
16
          key: ${{ runner.os }}-pip-${{ hashFiles('**/requirements.txt') }}
17
      - name: Install dependencies
18
        run: |
19
          python -m pip install --upgrade pip
20
          python -m pip install -r requirements.txt
21
      - name: Run ansible-lint
22
        run: |
23
          ansible-lint -v --show-relpath


This instructs the workflow to run on every pushed commit and every pull request.
First the action actions/check@v2 is used to set up the environment and checkout the repository.
The action actions/setup-python@v2 sets up Python, version 3.9 in my case.
Then I use the actions/cache@v2 to cache the Python dependencies I install in the following step.
I have a requirements.txt file in the root of the repository to track the required Python packages:




1
    ansible==4.2.0
2
    ansible-lint==5.0.12


The line path: ~/.cache/pip instructs the CI to cache the pip directory and key: … determines a key for the cache which is based on the operating system as well as the hash of the requirements.txt.
As long as the OS and the file do not change, the downloaded dependencies can be reused in the next step Install dependencies thus speeding up the workflow.
Of course one could also manually install ansible-lint with python -m pip install ansible-lint but that would require figuring out a different caching mechanism and would prevent Dependabot from checking for updates (see below).


In the last step Run ansible-lint the linter is actually executed.
Here, one could also change the CLI arguments used when calling ansible-lint, however it is much simpler to use a .ansible-lint file in the repository to configure it.
More on this topic can be found in the official documentation.
For example, it might be useful to exclude certain files that are not actually Ansible code:




1
    exclude_paths:
2
      - ".pre-commit-config.yaml"
3
      - "roles/vps/files/docker-compose-files"


As you can see, setting up ansible-lint as a GitHub action is pretty straightforward.
I have two final recommendations that you might find useful.
Dependabot can be used to check the packages used in the requirements.txt file for updates. Just create a file .github/dependabot.yml with the content




1
    version: 2
2
    updates:
3
      - package-ecosystem: "pip"
4
        directory: "/"
5
        schedule:
6
          interval: "daily"


to enable a daily update check. If Dependabot finds an update it will create a pull request for the repository.
You can add a nice badge to the README.md file indicating the workflow status using Shields.io. Select the "GitHub Workflow Status" and specify your repository and the workflow name. The name is specified by the first line in the workflow file (name: lint) so in my case it would be lint. Shields.io will then generate links, markdown, etc. to easily use the badge.


Two example repositories where I use this workflow can be found here:


    

  • dotfiles
    • 

  • playbooks
    •

entry.title: pelican-references
entry.summary: Handle references and bibliographies for pelican posts.
entry.content:
references: A Plugin for Pelican

Generate bibliographies from BibTeX files

Installation

This plugin can be installed via:

python -m pip install pelican-references

Usage

<>

Contributing

Contributions are welcome and much appreciated. Every little bit helps. You can contribute by improving the documentation, adding missing features, and fixing bugs. You can also help out by reviewing and commenting on existing issues.

To start contributing to this plugin, review the Contributing to Pelican documentation, beginning with the Contributing Code section.

License

This project is licensed under the AGPL-3.0 license.

entry.title: Bosonic quantum dynamics following colliding potential wells
entry.summary: We explore the dynamics of two interacting bosons confined in colliding potential wells using MCTDHB unraveling the fundamental processes that take place.
entry.content: We employ the multiconfiguration time-dependent Hartree method for bosons in order to investigate the correlated nonequilibrium quantum dynamics of two bosons confined in two colliding and uniformly accelerated Gaussian wells. As the wells approach each other an effective, transient double-well structure is formed. This induces a transient and oscillatory over-barrier transport. We monitor both the amplitude of the intrawell dipole mode in the course of the dynamics as well as the final distribution of the particles between the two wells. For fast collisions we observe an emission process which we attribute to two distinct mechanisms. Energy transfer processes lead to an untrapped fraction of bosons and a resonant enhancement of the deconfinement for certain kinematic configurations can be observed. Despite the comparatively weak interaction strengths employed in this work, we identify strong interparticle correlations by analyzing the corresponding von Neumann entropy.

entry.title: Shipping a Scientific Software Using AppImage
entry.summary: AppImages are portable binary application packages that run in most Linux environment. We show how it can be employed to distribute a multi-executable scientific software package including the Intel runtime without having to hand out the source code.
entry.content:
At my current PhD position I am the sole maintainer of a complex scientific software (an implementation of the ML-MCTDHX algorithm). Recently I found myself facing the challenge to distribute this package to users outside our group. Our code consists of two parts

  • a python library used for setting up the problem and analyzing results
  • Fortran binaries that do the actual number crunching

Distributing the Python was straightforward using the normal means. I just created a tarball using poetry build which can be installed using pip. Shipping the Fortran part however was not so straightforward, for the following reasons

  • The source code should not be shipped to the user.
  • The whole runtime (Intel runtime, MKL and system libraries) should be included, such that the software should run on any modern Linux platform
  • Avoid fiddling with environment variables (my first attempt was just to bundle everything up and update PATH and LD_LIBRARY_PATH, this was very error-prone, and I always forgot something).
  • The code should run on a Cluster where we cannot just install software like snap or flatpak.
  • The usage should be dead simple. Many scientists are not so tech-savvy and often are not interested in learning (which is OK, sometimes we just need to get our research done).

After looking at my options the solution became pretty clear – just build an AppImage. Using this tool chain you can package any Linux application into a single executable file.

In the following I describe how I obtained an AppImage from the existing CMake build system I wrote for the application. The procedure should be easy to adapt to other use cases/build systems as well. I test the result across multiple distributions using Docker.

Creating AppDir using CMake

The first step of the process is to create an AppDir using CMake. Our CMakeLists.txt file already creates an installation target using the install command. I added the following code

1
install(
2
  FILES
3
    $ENV{MKLROOT}/lib/intel64/libmkl_avx.so.1
4
    $ENV{MKLROOT}/lib/intel64/libmkl_avx2.so.1
5
    $ENV{MKLROOT}/lib/intel64/libmkl_avx512.so.1
6
    $ENV{MKLROOT}/lib/intel64/libmkl_avx512_mic.so.1
7
    $ENV{MKLROOT}/lib/intel64/libmkl_core.so.1
8
    $ENV{MKLROOT}/lib/intel64/libmkl_intel_lp64.so.1
9
    $ENV{MKLROOT}/lib/intel64/libmkl_sequential.so.1
10
    PERMISSIONS
11
      OWNER_READ OWNER_WRITE OWNER_EXECUTE
12
      GROUP_READ GROUP_EXECUTE
13
      WORLD_EXECUTE
14
    DESTINATION lib
15
    CONFIGURATIONS Release
16
)

which installs the necessary Intel MKL libraries. By adding

1
include(InstallRequiredSystemLibraries)

the rest of the Intel libraries including the Fortran runtime also gets bundled (see here). The idea is now to perform a normal CMake build and install the targets using the install target (e.g. make install). It is important to set CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/usr as this is the installation prefix the AppImage tool chain expects. The path where the executables will be located can be set using the DESTDIR variable and should be set to the AppDir to create for AppImage, e.g. DESTDIR=$PWD/build-appimage/AppDir.

In our example we end up with a directory structure like this:

1
qdtk.AppDir
2
└── usr
3
    ├── bin
4
    │   ├── qdtk_analysis.x
5
    │   ├── qdtk_expect.x
6
    │   └── qdtk_propagate.x
7
    └── lib
8
        ├── libchkp.so
9
        ├── libcilkrts.so
10
        ├── libcilkrts.so.5
11
        ├── libicaf.so
12
        ├── libifcoremt.so
13
        ├── libifcoremt.so.5
14
        ├── libifcore.so
15
        ├── libifcore.so.5
16
        ├── libifport.so
17
        ├── libifport.so.5
18
        ├── libimf.so
19
        ├── libintlc.so
20
        ├── libintlc.so.5
21
        ├── libiomp5.so
22
        ├── libiompstubs5.so
23
        ├── libirc.so
24
        ├── libirng.so
25
        ├── libmkl_avx2.so.1
26
        ├── libmkl_avx512_mic.so.1
27
        ├── libmkl_avx512.so.1
28
        ├── libmkl_avx.so.1
29
        ├── libmkl_core.so.1
30
        ├── libmkl_intel_lp64.so.1
31
        ├── libmkl_sequential.so.1
32
        ├── libmpx.so
33
        ├── libpdbx.so
34
        ├── libpdbx.so.5
35
        └── libsvml.so

Creating the AppImage

According to the documentation, the appimagetool command expects some extra files to be present. First we need to add an AppRun script which sets some environment variables and finally starts the software. The instructions recommend not to create it yourself. I just grabbed it from the git repository. Furthermore, a .desktop file is required (only the Name, Exec, Icon, Type and Categories fields have to be set). Mine looks like this:

1
[Desktop Entry]
2
Name=qdtk
3
Exec=qdtk
4
Icon=qdtk
5
Type=Application
6
Categories=Science;

The Exec field specifies the executable that the AppImage will execute. In my case this is the qdtk script which I describe in the next step, that dispatches the actual Fortran executable. An icon is required (here one really starts to notice that AppImage mainly targets graphical applications). I just dropped a blank 256x256 PNG file called qdtk.png in the AppDir and everything was fine.

To dispatch the actual executable I added a small wrapper script under usr/bin/qdtk in the AppDir:

1
#!/bin/sh
2
3
if [ "$#" -lt 1 ]; then
4
    echo "usage: qdtk.AppImage {qdtk_propagate.x|qdtk_expect.x|qdtk_analysis.x} [OPTIONS]"
5
    exit 1
6
else
7
    executable=$1
8
    shift
9
10
    case "$executable" in
11
        qdtk_propagate.x|qdtk_expect.x|qdtk_analysis.x)
12
            $executable $@
13
            ;;
14
        *)
15
            echo "usage: qdtk.AppImage {qdtk_propagate.x|qdtk_expect.x|qdtk_analysis.x} [OPTIONS]"
16
            ;;
17
    esac
18
fi


The first CLI option passed to qdtk.AppImage then specifies the executable (qdtk_propagate.x, qdtk_expect.x or qdtk_analysis.x) to call.
All remaining parameters are forwarded to that program.


The files added to the AppDir in this second step are:




1
qdtk.AppDir
2
├── AppRun
3
├── qdtk.desktop
4
├── qdtk.png
5
└── usr
6
    └── bin
7
        └── qdtk


Now, we can finally build the AppImage by calling appimagetool <path-to-appdir> qdtk.AppImage.
By calling qdtk.AppImage qdtk_propagate.x we can directly test it.
Luckily everything is now working and neatly bundled including all dependencies.


Testing Using Docker


In order to be sure that the AppImage we just created works across multiple distributions.
This can be easily achieved using Docker containers.
However, most Docker images ship without libfuse which is required to mount and run the AppImage.
Luckily AppImages can still be executed using the --appimage-extract-and-run flag by first extracting them.
As an example, I use the command




1
docker run \
2
    -v $PWD/build-appimage/qdtk.AppImage:/qdtk.AppImage \
3
    ubuntu:20.04 \
4
    /qdtk.AppImage --appimage-extract-and-run qdtk_propagate.x -h


to test the AppImage under Ubuntu 20.04 LTS.
I successfully tested my AppImage across multiple distributions.


In the future I will create a repository of Dockerfiles that add libfuse to the images of various distributions.
I will update this article accordingly once I found the time to do so.


Conclusions


Preparing an AppImage from our existing CMake project was surprisingly simple.
Everything I described should also work similarly for other build systems.
Now I have a nice self-contained package with all batteries included that I can just pass to the user.
At some points I noticed that the AppImage tool chain focuses on graphical desktop applications.
However, all these hurdles were easy to overcome.


My full script (executed from the project root directory, where CMakeLists.txt is located) is attached below.
Maybe it can serve you as a basis for your own experiments with AppImage.
It should be easy enough to adapt it to your use case.




1
#!/bin/bash
2
set -eu -o pipefail
3
4
# use all available cores for the compilation
5
export CMAKE_BUILD_PARALLEL_LEVEL=$(nproc --all)
6
7
# generate a Makefile build system in the folder build-appimage/cmake
8
cmake \
9
    -G "Unix Makefiles" \
10
    -S $PWD \
11
    -B $PWD/build-appimage/cmake \
12
    -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE:STRING=Release \
13
    -DCMAKE_Fortran_COMPILER:STRING=ifort \
14
    -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/usr \
15
    -DENABLE_MKL:BOOL=ON
16
17
# run the parallel build
18
nice -n 19 cmake --build build-appimage/cmake
19
20
# install binaries into the AppDir
21
make -C build-appimage/cmake install DESTDIR=$PWD/build-appimage/qdtk.AppDir
22
23
# copy extra files for AppImage as well as the wrapper script
24
cp -r AppDir/*  build-appimage/qdtk.AppDir/
25
26
# remove spurious home directory (left over from arpack ExternalProject
27
# TODO: figure out how to prevent this from happening
28
rm -rf build-appimage/qdtk.AppDir/home
29
30
# ensure that AppRun and the wrapper script remain executable
31
# AppImage does not preserve the permissions of these files
32
chmod a+x build-appimage/qdtk.AppDir/AppRun
33
chmod a+x build-appimage/qdtk.AppDir/usr/bin/qdtk
34
35
# build the AppImage
36
appimagetool build-appimage/qdtk.AppDir build-appimage/qdtk.AppImage
37
38
# test the AppImage across multiple distros
39
# TODO: build docker images including the libfuse library to avoid the
40
# extraction
41
docker run \
42
    -v $PWD/build-appimage/qdtk.AppImage:/qdtk.AppImage \
43
    ubuntu:16.04 \
44
    /qdtk.AppImage --appimage-extract-and-run qdtk_propagate.x -h
45
46
docker run \
47
    -v $PWD/build-appimage/qdtk.AppImage:/qdtk.AppImage \
48
    ubuntu:18.04 \
49
    /qdtk.AppImage --appimage-extract-and-run qdtk_propagate.x -h
50
51
docker run \
52
    -v $PWD/build-appimage/qdtk.AppImage:/qdtk.AppImage \
53
    ubuntu:20.04 \
54
    /qdtk.AppImage --appimage-extract-and-run qdtk_propagate.x -h
55
56
docker run \
57
    -v $PWD/build-appimage/qdtk.AppImage:/qdtk.AppImage \
58
    archlinux \
59
    /qdtk.AppImage --appimage-extract-and-run qdtk_propagate.x -h

entry.title: pelican-math-svg
entry.summary: Render mathematical expressions for your pelican site to SVG in a smart way.
entry.content:
math-svg: A Plugin for Pelican

Render math expressions to svg and embed them.

Installation

This plugin can be installed via:

1
python -m pip install pelican-math-svg

Afterwards, add the plugin to the PLUGINS list in your pelicanconf.py file, e.g.:

1
PLUGINS = [
2
    "math_svg",
3
]

Multi-Core Rendering

To use multi-core rendering of equations (highly recommended, especially when many equations have to be rendered) change the html target in the Makefile of your pelican site to a three step process:

1
html:
2
    PELICAN_MATH_SVG_DRY=True "$(PELICAN)" "$(INPUTDIR)" -o "$(OUTPUTDIR)" -s "$(CONFFILE)" $(PELICANOPTS)
3
    pelican-math-svg render -j $(shell nproc)
4
    "$(PELICAN)" "$(INPUTDIR)" -o "$(OUTPUTDIR)" -s "$(CONFFILE)" $(PELICANOPTS)

The first commands will execute math-svg in dry-mode and only populate the equation database without actually rendering anything. The second command will render all missing equations in parallel. The number of threads is specified by the -j flag, in this example all CPU cores are used. Replace $(shell nproc) with a number to use a fixed number of cores. The last command is the usual pelican command and produces the output files again, know including the rendered equations.

Requirements

  • required LaTeX tools (all included in TeX Live and possibly other LaTeX distributions): - lualatex (or another LaTeX compiler if changed in the settings, see below) - pdfcrop - dvisvgm
  • scour (optional)
  • svgo (optional)

Usage

In Markdown you can use for inline math and

1
$$
2
  \int x^2
3
$$

for display math.

It is required to set the stroke color using the strokeonly class (this class name can be changed, see configuration options below), otherwise lines would be rendered white:

1
svg path.strokeonly {
2
    color: #000;
3
}

To change the fill color for equations as well, thus essential changing the default color for math, specify the following additionally:

1
span.math svg path,
2
div.math svg path {
3
    fill: #000;
4
}

Configuration

In your pelicanconf.py you can use the following options to tweak the behavior of the plugin:

Setting Description Default Value
MATH_SVG["titles"] | Whether to generate<code>tags containing the raw LaTeX code (recommended for accessibility). |</code>True`
MATH_SVG["scale_inline"] scaling factor for inline math 1.0
MATH_SVG["scale_display"] scaling factor for display math 1.0
MATH_SVG["strokeonly_class] CSS class for SVG paths that have no filling and a black stroke color, useful when changing the color of rendered equations strokeonly
MATH_SVG["latex"]["args"] CLI arguments of the invoked LaTeX compiler "--interaction=errorstopmode", "--halt-on-error"
MATH_SVG["latex"]["preamble"] preamble of the generated LaTeX document [r"\documentclass[preview,border={2pt 0pt}]{standalone}",r"\usepackage{amsmath}",r"\usepackage{amssymb}",]
MATH_SVG["latex"]["program"] LaTeX compiler to use lualatex
MATH_SVG["pdfcrop"]["args"] CLI arguments for pdfcrop --hires
MATH_SVG["dvisvgm"]["args"] CLI arguments for dvisvgm ["--pdf", "--optimize=all", "--no-fonts", "--exact-bbox"]
MATH_SVG["scour"]["args"] CLI arguments for scour ["--strip-xml-prolog", "--remove-descriptions", "--remove-metadata", "--enable-comment-stripping", "--strip-xml-space", "--enable-id-stripping",]
MATH_SVG["scour"]["enabled"] whether to use scour to optimize SVG output True if scour is in $PATH, False otherwise
MATH_SVG["svgo"]["args"] CLI arguments for svgo ["--multipass", "--precision", "5"]
MATH_SVG["svgo"]["enabled"] whether to use svgo to optimize SVG output True if svgo is in $PATH, False otherwise

Contributing

Contributions are welcome and much appreciated. Every little bit helps. You can contribute by improving the documentation, adding missing features, and fixing bugs. You can also help out by reviewing and commenting on existing issues.

To start contributing to this plugin, review the Contributing to Pelican documentation, beginning with the Contributing Code section.

License

This project is licensed under the GPLv3 license.

entry.title: Dynamical Pruning of the Non-Equilibrium Quantum Dynamics of Trapped Ultracold Bosons
entry.summary: The exponentially growing Hilbert space of many-body systems as a function of system sizes poses a major challenge for numerical methods. We explore how a dynamical pruning approach can be employed within the framework of MCTDHB in order to reduce the computational effort.
entry.content: The investigation of the nonequilibrium quantum dynamics of bosonic many-body systems is very challenging due to the excessively growing Hilbert space and poses a major problem for their theoretical description and simulation. We present a novel dynamical pruning approach in the framework of the multiconfiguration time-dependent Hartree method for bosons (MCTDHB) to tackle this issue by dynamically detecting the most relevant number states of the underlying physical system and modifying the many-body Hamiltonian accordingly. We discuss two different number state selection criteria as well as two different ways to modify the Hamiltonian. Our scheme regularly re-evaluates the number state selection in order to dynamically adapt to the time evolution of the system. To benchmark our methodology, we study the nonequilibrium dynamics of bosonic particles confined either in an optical lattice or in a double-well potential. It is shown that our approach reproduces the unpruned MCTDHB results accurately while yielding a significant reduction of the simulation time. The speedup is particularly pronounced in the case of the optical lattice.

entry.title: cpp-perf
entry.summary: Small header-only C++11 to measure code execution time and performance.
entry.content:
cpp-perf

A small, header-only performance measurement library for C++11.

Most basic usage

1
#include <cpp-perf.hpp>
2
3
int main()
4
{
5
    perf::start();
6
    std::this_thread::sleep_for(perf::milliseconds(20));
7
    perf::stop();
8
9
    return 0;
10
}


Output:




1
20 ms


Inline measurement




1
#include <cpp-perf.hpp>
2
3
int main() {
4
    PERF_START();
5
    std::this_thread::sleep_for(perf::milliseconds(20));
6
7
    PERF_START();
8
    for(int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
9
        std::this_thread::sleep_for(perf::milliseconds(20));
10
    }
11
    PERF_STOP();
12
13
    PERF_STOP();
14
15
    return 0;
16
}


Output:




1
/somepath/perf/example/inline.cpp:main:7-11: 200ms
2
/somepath/perf/example/inline.cpp:main:4-13: 220ms


If you put #ifdef PERF_DISABLE_INLINE in front of the include #include <cpp-perf.hpp> there will no measurement be performed. The macros are actually expanded int empty lines so that your code is the same as if you would not have put them there.


Automatic suite




1
#include <cpp-perf.hpp>
2
PERF_BEGIN("ExampleModule")
3
4
PERF_CASE("example1",
5
    std::this_thread::sleep_for(perf::milliseconds(20));
6
)
7
8
PERF_CASE("example1",
9
    for(int i = 0; i < 20; i++) std::this_thread::sleep_for(perf::milliseconds(30));
10
)
11
12
PERF_END()


Output:




1
1/2 Case #1: example1 .....................  Passed  20 ms
2
2/2 Case #2: example2 .....................  Passed  601 ms


Manual suites




1
#include <cpp-perf.hpp>
2
3
// you can use functions
4
bool example2() {
5
    std::this_thread::sleep_for(perf::milliseconds(100));
6
    return true;
7
}
8
9
// you can use functors
10
struct example3 {
11
    bool operator()() {
12
        // exceptions will be caught
13
        throw std::string("This fails!");
14
        return true;
15
    }
16
};
17
18
int main()
19
{
20
    example3 functor;
21
22
    // you can add cases via the constructor
23
    perf::suite suite({
24
        // you can use lambdas
25
        { "example1", []() { std::this_thread::sleep_for(perf::milliseconds(40)); return true; } },
26
        { "example2", example2},
27
        { "example3", functor}
28
    });
29
30
    // you can add cases later
31
    suite.add_case("example4", []() { std::this_thread::sleep_for(perf::microseconds(800)); return true; });
32
33
    // run all cases at once
34
    suite.run();
35
36
    // print results
37
    std::cout << suite << std::endl;
38
39
    return 0;
40
}


Output:




1
1/4 Case #1: example1 .....................  Passed  40 ms
2
2/4 Case #2: example2 .....................  Passed  100 ms
3
3/4 Case #3: example3 .....................  Failed  61 μs
4
4/4 Case #4: example4 .....................  Passed  859 μs

entry.title: Binet's Formula and Linear Algebra
entry.summary: Binet's formula can be used to compute an arbitrary member of the Fibonacci sequence. In this post we show how it can be easily derived using some basic linear algebra.
